It is with great sadness that we share the news of the passing of Scotty Shevlin. Scotty was “the voice” of Dobbs Ferry High School football for the past 39 years, and called the play-by-play at Gould for countless championships and state titles.

Part of what makes Dobbs Ferry such a special place is our proud history, and Scotty Shevlin will forever be part of the fabric of our village. While this is a sad day in Dobbs Ferry, we also join together to celebrate a life well lived. Rest In Peace, Scotty.

A Story ... While cleaning up some old files in the band room last year, music teacher Paul Huneke stumbled across the music for the DFHS Alma Mater. He did a little investigating, and from what he could find, it hadn't been performed publicly in many years, maybe over a decade. (Paul would be curious to know if it is familiar to any of you.)
He didn't know what to do with it at the time, but figured this teaching situation was a good chance to explore a little Dobbs Ferry history, work on his video editing skills and share some music with the community. Please enjoy the performance! Click to see the video https://youtu.be/hVvLoVGTJ6E

March 29 at 10:31 PM ·

Congratulations to Gayathri Nair! She won first place in her poster competition at Upstate Junior Science and Humanities Symposium! This state level competition has been held annually in Albany but they figured out a virtual solution 😊 YAY!

Nair's research focused on developing a deeper understanding of Toxoplasmosis. Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection. The parasite, Toxoplasma gondii, has been historically difficult to eradicate during infections due to its ability to defend itself against antibiotics. Nair was able to identify a possible genetic approach to disarming the parasite, thus making the illness more easily treatable.

This is the kind of research our world truly needs, these days! Great job, Gaya3!! ❤️❤️

Tuesday: Build a fort

Wednesday: Pajama Day
Wear your favorite pajamas!

Thursday: Jers-day
Wear your favorite sports Jersey!

Friday: Formal
Take a picture of yourself doing your school work all dressed up!

Remember to follow @dfhsvirtualcommons on Instagram and look for posts of you and your friends!

Warm Regards,
Mrs. Addona

IB French Trip to Montréal and Québec!

Madame Irvine's IB French class spent 5 beautiful days enjoying the art, culture, and cuisine of Montréal and Québec. The students were able to practice their French throughout this wonderful experience.

Some of the highlights included the Musée des Beaux-Arts, an evening historical ghost tour through the cobblestoned streets of Old Montréal, and the Notre Dame Basilica. They then traveled on to Quebec to stay at the magnificent Château Frontenac. The students had a lesson in the sport of curling, took part in an interactive "day in the life" of a soldier in the Martello Tower, and finally enjoyed folk songs and dancing at an authentic Sugar Shack, where they made taffy lollipops from the maple syrup. The students also had some free time to ice skate, snap pictures and shop in charming Old Québec.

The trip concluded with a ferry ride across the beautiful Saint Lawrence River before heading back to Dobbs Ferry. A special thank you to Madame Irvine for organizing this entire trip and to Signora Addona for chaperoning!

Service Learning at DFHS!

Our 10th graders have been reading Richard Wright's memoir, Black Boy. The memoir chronicles Richard's experience growing up in a time of extreme poverty, hunger and racism in the deep south. As our students discussed Richard's hunger regularly in class, they came up with the idea that they would like to sponsor a Thanksgiving dinner for a local family in need.

As part of this project, our students came up with great ideas (such as printing out word searches and little coloring pages for the children - things that don't cost anything so that everyone could get involved). They brought in items, made little signs, and even went on a field trip to Stop & Shop to shop for the items.

The baskets look wonderful and are full of food and fun Thanksgiving treats. We are very proud of their efforts! A special thanks to Ms. Fahy, Ms. Cosgrove, and Ms. Castellano for organizing this! #GenerationIB #DFHSIB20

DFHS Science Research Students Win at International Competition, Genius Olympiad!

This past week, five DFHS Science Research juniors attended the International Genius Olympiad in Oswego, NY. This prestigious opportunity was awarded to them based on their science research papers and presentations. The students presented their research along with nearly 1,000 other students from around the globe! And they were all recognized for their achievements in their fields!

Isabel Long and Jamie Kramer were awarded Silver Medals, Abigail Bayer-Mertens Human was awarded a Bronze Medal, and Gabriella Torres and Isabel Danishmend both received Honorable Mentions.

Additionally, the students who were named as medalists are being offered the opportunity to publish their papers in the International Journal of High School Research, a peer-reviewed publication designed for high school research.

Congratulations to these hard-working young scientists!!

DFHS Sophomore Wins a Chester!

Erika Totoro's short film, Lonely, was awarded the Chester for Most Creative Film at the 18th annual Future Filmmakers Film Festival. Originally made for her MYP Personal Project in Ms. Cairo’s class, the film is Erika's first claymation short. She personally designed and sculpted all of the characters, props, and sets, and then took over 2,500 still frame photos to create a fluid and engaging stop-motion about a lonely doughnut in search of a friend. Of the thirty-seven films in competition, Erika's stood apart as the only animation and was well received by the judges who remarked on her original vision and hard work. She looks forward to continuing her work with clay and stop-motion animation.

DFHS Trip to Spain!

A group of DFHS 18 juniors and seniors, along with 3 faculty chaperones, took off on the trip of a lifetime to Spain over spring break. The trip consisted of five beautiful spanish cities: Barcelona, Córdoba, Granada, Madrid and Toledo. Highlights of the trip included; touring the Sagrada Familia in Barcelona, the Mezquita in Córdoba, the Alhambra in Granada, the Prado museum in Madrid, and a Flamenco and cooking lesson all in Spanish! It was truly an amazing experience for all of the students and teachers alike! The trip was led by IB Spanish Teacher Megan Lois with the help of chaperones Maria Milio and Lisa Honeck.
